void.string: In this lecture, Professor Mike Mochizuki discusses the evolution and likely trajectory of US-Japanese security relations following the return of the Liberal Democratic Party and Shinzo Abe to Power, and the Obama Administration's "rebalancing" toward Asia. Professor Mochizuki also explores the role of the US-Japan alliance, the rise of China and the impact of uncertainties in the Korean peninsula. He explores the Senkaku/Diaoyu Islands dispute, the challenges of maritime security, the Taiwan question, and the US-China nuclear balance and extended deterrence. He looks at options for dealing with North Korea and explore the implications of various scenarios for both Japanese security policy and the US-Japan alliance.And finally, Professor Mochizuki addresses bilateral defence cooperation, Abe's push to reinterpret and revise Japan's constitution, the impact of fiscal constraints, and the Futenma Marine Air Station relocation plan and Okinawan politics.Professor Mochizuki holds the Japan-U.S. Relations Chair in Memory of Gaston Sigur at the Elliott School of International Affairs at The George Washington University. Dr. Mochizuki was director of the Sigur Center for Asian Studies from 2001 to 2005. He co-directs the "Memory and Reconciliation in the Asia-Pacific" research and policy project of the Sigur Center. Previously, he was a Senior Fellow at the Brookings Institution. He was also Co-Director of the Center for Asia-Pacific Policy at RAND and has taught at the University of Southern California and Yale University.This event is co-hosted by the ANU Japan Institute, the Department of Strategic & Defence Studies Centre, Department of Political & Social Change, the National Security College and the ARC Centre of Excellence in Policing and Security. viewcount:0 Time:null

In this lecture, Professor Mike Mochizuki discusses the evolution and likely trajectory of US-Japanese security relations following the return of the Liberal Democratic Party and Shinzo Abe to Power, and the Obama Administration's "rebalancing" toward Asia. Professor Mochizuki also explores the role of the US-Japan alliance, the rise of China and the impact of uncertainties in the Korean peninsula. He explores the Senkaku/Diaoyu Islands dispute, the challenges of maritime security, the Taiwan question, and the US-China nuclear balance and extended deterrence. He looks at options for dealing with North Korea and explore the implications of various scenarios for both Japanese security policy and the US-Japan alliance.And finally, Professor Mochizuki addresses bilateral defence cooperation, Abe's push to reinterpret and revise Japan's constitution, the impact of fiscal constraints, and the Futenma Marine Air Station relocation plan and Okinawan politics.Professor Mochizuki holds the Japan-U.S. Relations Chair in Memory of Gaston Sigur at the Elliott School of International Affairs at The George Washington University. Dr. Mochizuki was director of the Sigur Center for Asian Studies from 2001 to 2005. He co-directs the "Memory and Reconciliation in the Asia-Pacific" research and policy project of the Sigur Center. Previously, he was a Senior Fellow at the Brookings Institution. He was also Co-Director of the Center for Asia-Pacific Policy at RAND and has taught at the University of Southern California and Yale University.This event is co-hosted by the ANU Japan Institute, the Department of Strategic & Defence Studies Centre, Department of Political & Social Change, the National Security College and the ARC Centre of Excellence in Policing and Security.
A Pivotal Alliance? US-Japan relations and East Asian security
